content.description:
It starts with a layback on a fairly solid crack with decent hand within. You ride a crack for 1-2 moves, and then go for a solid, high left hand. There's a solid cobble pocket just above that left hand, then there's a good angle to put right foot high, and then get another solid pocket for your right hand. Then make a decent reach to a sweet indented jug, and then just finish with a careful topout. It's

guaranteed this line has been climbed, but due to it not being in MP or in guidebook, I'll call it FKA (First Known Ascent).
content.location:
This is on far right of Fountainbleau Boulder around the corner from

Traverse

, V4, on the Northern side of the border. It rides the prominent crack to decent holds. There was no chalk and nothing in the guidebook or on Mt. Proj. about this route, so I though it was a worthy submission.

content.description: On the Stage Boulder's (Fountainbleau's?) East face is a fun problem.  Just right of the small crack/seam with a pocket is Up Staged.  A matching pair of crimps at chest level is the start.  There are no positive holds on top except for a nice pocket jug above the seam.
content.protection: A crashpad is useful but not necessary.

content.description: This is a left-to-right traverse across the Fountainebleau Boulder. Start sitting using two low pockets on the far left end of the face. Initially move up and right, and then traverse rightwards at about mid-height with some slightly harder moves on slopers near the end of the face, turn the corner, and finish up on the good pockets of the corner, V0.
content.protection: Pads. There is a mostly soft landing, but there is a boulder beneath your feet at the end of the traverse.
content.location: This is on the main face of the Fontainbleu Boulder.

content.description:
This problem starts the same as

East Face Left

(aka Exit Stage Left) but moves to top out to the right.

climbs.name: Exit Stage Left (submitted as East Face, Left Side)

content.description:
This problem starts left of

Up Staged

at two low pockets. Good balance, crimps, and a sloper lead to the top. I found this problem a little harder than

Up Staged

.

Start low on the boulder to the right of

Up Staged

.
This is the farthest right V0 route on the east face of the boulder.

pathTokens: Denver Metropolitan Area Bouldering and Buildering
